awd_titl_txt: Type II: University of Pittsburgh I-Corps Site:  Advancing Innovation, Entreprenuership and Opportunity Commercialization
awd_abstract_narration:
This University of Pittsburgh (Pitt) project builds on an existing I-Corps Site under the University's Innovation Institute.

NSF Innovation Corps (I-Corps) Sites are NSF-funded entities established at universities whose purpose is to nurture and support multiple, local teams to transition their technology concepts into the marketplace. Sites provide infrastructure, advice, resources, networking opportunities, training and modest funding to enable groups to transition their work into the marketplace or into becoming I-Corps Team applicants. I-Corps Sites also strengthen innovation locally and regionally and contribute to the National Innovation Network of mentors, researchers, entrepreneurs and investors. This is a Type II project, requesting a "renewal" of funding for an existing I-Corps Site. There are two types of I-Corps Site proposals. Type I proposals are submitted by institutions that have not had prior funding as an I-Corps Site. Type II proposals are submitted by institutions that have had prior funding as an I-Corps Site. 

The main objectives of the Type II Pitt I-Corps Site include: -Increase the number of entrepreneurial minded individuals on campus through education/training with an emphasis on disciplines and individuals underrepresented in current commercialization offerings -Enhance the Pitt Ventures program through addition of a starter course focused on supplementing viable innovations from campus with key steps required to move them to market -Improve Pitt's connection to the regional entrepreneurial ecosystem for enhanced integration with the local early-stage environment and similar networks beyond Pittsburgh.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: UNIVERSITY OF PITTSBURGH - OF THE COMMONWEALTH SYSTEM OF HIGHER EDUCATION

por.por_cntn:
The specific objectives of the University of Pittsburgh (Pitt) National Science Foundation (NSF) I-Corps Site award are as follows:

• Objective 1: Increasing the number of entrepreneurial-minded individuals by educating training and outreach to departments with scientific disciplines and individuals underrepresented in current commercialization processes.

• Objective 2: Enhancing the Pitt Ventures commercialization process focused on supplementing viable innovations from the laboratory with key steps required to move them to the market; and

• Objective 3: Improving connection to the regional entrepreneurial ecosystem for enhanced integration of Pitt opportunities into the local early-stage environment and similar networks beyond Pittsburgh.

Under this NSF I-Corps Site award, Pitt ran 15 I-Corps cohorts through which it trained 111 NSF funded teams, including 111 faculty, 133 students, and 141 mentor assignments with 83 volunteer mentors. Teams came from 28 Pitt departments including: Anesthesiology & Perioperative Medicine, Critical Care Medicine, Department of Neurology,  Rheumatology & Clinical Immunology, Neurological Surgery, Ophthalmology, Pathology, Pediatrics, Pulmonary Medicine, Physical Medicine & Rehabilitation, Plastic Surgery, Psychology, Nursing, Oncology, Radiology, Bioengineering, Chemical Engineering, Civil & Environmental Engineering, Chemistry, Computer Science, Social Work, and Sports Medicine and Nutrition. Each team has received basic training in customer discovery and business model canvas hypotheses and has received detailed feedback from I-Corps administrators.

All participating teams attended six 2½ hour training sessions, during which they learned about the basics of the business model canvas, customer interview methodology, product-market fit, determining market size, competitive analysis, and follow-on funding opportunities. Additional topics also included introducing university and regional resources for market and competitive analysis, creation of elevator pitch, and pitch deck development and presentation. Each cohort culminatesd with a pitch deck presentation to university and regional entrepreneurial judges for feedback and monetary awards. Each team met one-on-one with the instructors during office hours sessions and pitch deck rehearsals, and benefited from having an outside business mentor to guide their team throughout the process.

Fourteen companies have been formed by I-Corps graduate teams during the period of the I-Corps renewal grant in addition to twenty-six startups formed by I-Corps teams during the original grant. Several recent I-Corps Site graduates have been accepted to regional accelerator programs like Innovation Works AlphaLab Health. Pitt I-Corps graduates have also received over $92 million in follow-on funding, including 9 SBIR/STTR awards, totaling more than $3.6 million in federal funding.

 

 


Last Modified: 02/22/2024
Modified by: Evan Facher
